net.cloud.gfx.elements.modal

Class AbstractModalDialog

  • java.lang.Object
    • net.cloud.gfx.elements.AbstractElement
      • net.cloud.gfx.elements.PriorityContainer
        • net.cloud.gfx.elements.Interface
          • net.cloud.gfx.elements.modal.AbstractModalDialog
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Container<Element>, Element, Focusable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    ConfirmationDialog, InputDialog, MessageDialog, TestModalDialog

    public abstract class AbstractModalDialog
extends Interface
    Abstract base class for modal dialog interfaces. A modal dialog is an interface that appears on top of all other elements, and demands focus. (The attention whore!) While this element in itself does not enforce this behavior, that is the intended behavior and should be enforced by the outside system. (Enforce the assertion that only one modal dialog may be present at any time, and it will receive all input.)
    Notable things this superclass does: Trap key events so they will not move up the parent hierarchy, prevent linking to other focusable, and disallowing changes to the priority.

    • Method Detail

      • drawElement

        public void drawElement(java.awt.Graphics g,
                        int offsetX,
                        int offsetY)
                 throws IteratorException
        Calls super.drawElement() first. Then, if the dialog has a highlight color (from a click happening off of it), that highlight color will be drawn over the dialog. The highlight fades somewhat quickly.
        Specified by:
        drawElement in interface Element
        Overrides:
        drawElement in class Interface
        Parameters:
        g - The graphics object to draw to
        offsetX - How far off on the X axis this element is from the Graphic's origin
        offsetY - How far off on the Y axis this element is from the Graphic's origin
        Throws:
        IteratorException - If the Container's list of children was modified during drawing

      • keyTyped

        public void keyTyped(char key)
        Key events will not propagate to parents of the modal dialogue. In other words, this traps key events and does nothing.
        Specified by:
        keyTyped in interface Element
        Specified by:
        keyTyped in interface Focusable
        Overrides:
        keyTyped in class AbstractElement
        Parameters:
        key - The character which was typed

      • linkNextFocusable

        public void linkNextFocusable(Focusable current,
                              Focusable next)
        Cannot change focus from a modal dialog. It wants to keep it. Will always throw UnsupportedOperationException
        Specified by:
        linkNextFocusable in interface Focusable
        Overrides:
        linkNextFocusable in class PriorityContainer
        Parameters:
        current - The focusable object being linked to next
        next - The next Focusable in line
        Throws:
        java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - Always.

      • setPriority

        public void setPriority(int priority)
        Cannot change the priority of a modal dialog. It relies on this to maintain its always-on-top behavior. Will always throw UnsupportedOperationException
        Specified by:
        setPriority in interface Element
        Overrides:
        setPriority in class AbstractElement
        Parameters:
        priority - The new priority of the element. This will not have an effect unless re-added to the container.
        Throws:
        java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - Always.

      • offDialogClick

        public void offDialogClick()
        Notify the dialog that a click was made off of it. This will cause the dialog to show some kind of visual notice to the user that the dialog wants attention. FEED IT! (Bad humor?)

      • removeDialog

        public void removeDialog()
        Remove the dialog from its parent and deregister it
